channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Russia Starts Day With Attacks Across Ukraine
item.description: There was heavy fire at and from Mykolaiv on Saturday morning, a day after Russian forces opened fire on a cancer hospital in the southern city. Air-raid sirens sounded in cities across the country before dawn.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising over the area south of Kyiv on Saturday after a night of numerous and heavy explosions around the capital city.

item.title: How a Line of Russian Tanks Became an Inviting Target for Ukrainians
item.description: A skirmish in an eastern suburb of Kyiv illustrated how close Russian forces have come as they continued to tighten a noose on the city, but also revealed their strategic vulnerabilities.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Destroyed Russian tanks are seen on a main road after battles near Brovary, north of Kyiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Europe’s Trains Take Fighters to Ukraine, and Bring Back Refugees
item.description: Built up over 150 years of conflicts that defined modern-day Europe, railways have played a central role in the continent’s peacetime integration. Now they’re back on a war footing.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians Vitali Slobodianiuk, right, and Volodymyr Kotsyuba on a train from Prague to Przemysl in Poland. They were going back to Ukraine to join the fight against Russia’s invading army.

item.title: Russian Demands to Ease Sanctions Halt Nuclear Talks With Iran
item.description: Russia has injected its fight against sanctions into talks aimed at restoring a nuclear agreement with Iran. The Russian demands have delayed the prospect of a deal.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: The Bushehr nuclear power plant in Iran in 2010. Tehran, which wants the removal of economic sanctions the United States has imposed on it, has criticized the new Russian demands.

item.title: Russian Sieges in Ukraine Are Triggering Flashbacks for Syrians.
item.description: “We feel for them and say, may God be with you,” said one Syrian who endured hunger and cold when his own government, backed by Russia, besieged Aleppo.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: A man walked down a street damaged by shelling in Mariupol, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: ‘Hurricane Hazel’ Is Still a Force at 101, and After 36 Years as Mayor
item.description: After playing pro hockey in the 1940s, Hazel McCallion entered politics at a time when few women held high office, leading a major Canadian city through epic growth. Her endorsements still matter.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Tara Walton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hazel McCallion at her home in Mississauga, Ontario.

item.title: China Has Tools to Help Russia’s Economy. None Are Big Enough to Save It.
item.description: Any financial lifeline that Beijing can offer Moscow involves taking on risk and won’t have the power to reverse the damage of sanctions imposed by the United States and its allies.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, the leader of China, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow in 2019.

item.title: Kamala Harris Says U.S. Must Bear Higher Gas Prices to Punish Russia
item.description: Vice President Kamala Harris, visiting NATO ally Romania, insisted that the higher costs of energy associated with sanctions imposed on Moscow over its war on Ukraine would be worth the pain.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris met with President Klaus Iohannis of Romania in Otopeni, Romania, on Friday.

item.title: Saudi Blogger Raif Badawi Is Released From Prison
item.description: Amnesty International welcomed news of the release of Raif Badawi, whose case became a lightening rod for rights campaigners and reflected Saudi Arabia’s lack of tolerance for dissent.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Ensaf Haidar holding a portrait of her husband, Raif Badawi, in France in 2015.

item.title: Yogi Adityanath’s Election Win Raises His Profile Across India
item.description: Yogi Adityanath’s return as chief minister of Uttar Pradesh is fueling talk that he might succeed Narendra Modi as prime minister one day, and continue to advance their Hindu political movement.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yogi Adityanath, center, and Bharatiya Janata Party supporters celebrate in Lucknow, the capital of Uttar Pradesh, on Thursday.

item.title: Leaders of Sarah Everard Vigil Had Rights Violated by Police, Court Rules
item.description: The judgment comes at a particularly fraught time for London’s Metropolitan Police Service, and as Parliament considers a law that would broaden police powers to clamp down on protests.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: London police officers at a vigil for Sarah Everard in March 2021.

item.title: As Ireland’s Church Retreats, the Cult of a Female Saint Thrives
item.description: The cult of Saint Brigid, with its emphasis on nature and healing, and its shift away from the patriarchal faith of traditional Catholicism in Ireland, is attracting people from around the world.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pilgrim washing her feet while praying at St. Brigid’s Well on St. Brigid’s Day, Feb. 1, on the outskirts of Kildare, Ireland.

item.title: Zachary Rolfe Acquitted of Murder of Kumanjayi Walker in Australia
item.description: Many Indigenous Australians had seen the case as a test of whether the authorities could be held accountable after what they call decades of abuses.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Zachary Rolfe, center, arriving at court last week in Darwin, Australia. He faced charges including murder.

item.title: How Billionaires Are Shaping France’s Presidential Campaign
item.description: In a nation with strict political finance laws, control over the news media has provided an avenue for the very rich to influence elections, this one more than ever.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A campaign rally for Éric Zemmour, a French far-right presidential candidate, last month. He has set the themes of the race with the anti-immigrant and anti-Muslim views he had put forth on television in recent years.

item.title: Ukrainian Minister Has Turned Digital Tools Into Modern Weapons of War
item.description: Mykhailo Fedorov, Ukraine’s youngest minister, has turned technology, cryptocurrency and social media into modern weapons of war.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:description: Mykhailo Fedorov, a vice prime minister of Ukraine and former tech entrepreneur, in 2020.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth is Skipping Next Week’s Commonwealth Day Service
item.description: It is still less than a month since the British monarch tested positive for the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Gaitri Issar Kumar, the high commissioner of India, greeting Queen Elizabeth II via videolink on Tuesday. Ms. Kumar was at Buckingham Palace; the queen was in Windsor Castle.

item.title: Slowed on the Battlefield, Russia Widens Bombardment of Ukrainian Cities
item.description: But military experts, citing previous Russian campaigns, say that strategy is unlikely to succeed without bloody urban fighting.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson, Eric Schmitt and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: An explosion Friday after a Russian army tank fired on an apartment building in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: American Officials Believe They Have Located Putin’s Yacht
item.description: They say they have indications that the $700 million, 459-foot yacht, which is in dry dock in Italy, is associated with the Russian president, backing an earlier claim by a former crew member.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Michael Forsythe, David D. Kirkpatrick and Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: The Scheherazade dominates the waterfront in the small Italian town of Marina di Carrara where it has been moored since September.

item.title: The New Captain of the Endurance Shipwreck Is an Anemone
item.description: A who’s who of the new invertebrate crew steering Ernest Shackleton’s sunken ship in the Weddell Sea.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler
item.media:credit: Falklands Maritime Heritage Trust, NOAA Exploration and Research, Alamy

item.title: Parents Relying on Ukraine Surrogates Desperately Seek Their Newborns
item.description: The Russian invasion has disrupted a thriving hub of legal commercial surrogacy. Some couples are risking trips into the war zone to get their children.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:description: A rescue team evacuated Lenny and Moishe, making a daylong journey from Kyiv to Rzeszow, Poland.

item.title: How The New York Times Verifies Reporting on the Ukraine War
item.description: To cut through the fog of propaganda and misinformation on both sides, The Times has deployed dozens of journalists to Ukraine to witness events as they unfold.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier running to check on a family after a mortar shell exploded on a civilian evacuation route in Irpin, Ukraine.

item.title: How Roman Abramovich, a Russian Oligarch, Found Himself Under Sanctions
item.description: The oligarch’s billions and his Kremlin connections secured him favors and elite status in the West. Now they’ve landed him on a sanctions list.
item.dc:creator: David D. Kirkpatrick, Isabel Kershner, Rory Smith and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: On Thursday, Britain froze the assets of Roman Abramovich, the billionaire owner of the Chelsea Football Club.

item.title: Over Ukraine, Lumbering Turkish-Made Drones Are an Ominous Sign for Russia
item.description: The Bayraktar TB2 has become a rallying symbol for Ukrainians, who are singing songs about them and posting videos of their success.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Bayraktar TB2 drones are assembled in Turkey, but rely extensively on electronics made in the United States and Canada.

item.title: Theory About U.S.-Funded Bioweapons Labs in Ukraine Is Unfounded
item.description: Prominent conservative voices have mischaracterized remarks from American officials to amplify baseless claims promoted by Russian state media.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:description: The White House, Pentagon and State Department have all unequivocally denied the claims about biological weapons laboratories in Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine’s Architectural Treasures Face Destruction
item.description: The country’s vast array of historic buildings, artworks and public squares are an integral part of Ukraine’s cultural identity. Amid the violence of war, many are being reduced to rubble.
item.dc:creator: Evan Rail
item.media:description: A centuries-old statue of Christ was removed from the Armenian Cathedral in Lviv for safekeeping.

item.title: Overwhelmed Hong Kong Hospitals Keep Dead Near Covid Patients
item.description: For several weeks, bodies have been piling up at hospitals because the city’s public mortuaries, which can take up to 3,000 bodies, are full.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: A person was loaded onto a transfer bus outside Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Hong Kong on Thursday.

item.title: Disabled Chinese Fight for Equal Rights Despite Paralympic Glory
item.description: Outside the Games, people with disabilities in China face discrimination and a lack of opportunities. “I’ve been struggling to survive,” said one former Paralympian.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Liu Mengtao of China won gold at the 2022 Winter Paralympics in Beijing. The Chinese government has held up such successes as a symbol of its efforts to advance the rights of people with disabilities.

item.title: U.S. and Allies Will Strip Russia of Favored Trade Status
item.description: The Biden administration said it would join Europe and other allies in stripping Russia of permanent normal trade relations, another step to inflict economic damage on the country over its invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times

item.title: Australia Weighs Lifting Covid Isolation Rules for Close Contacts
item.description: The country is shifting from trying to prevent all transmission of the virus toward protecting those most vulnerable. “There will inevitably be a level of virus within the community going forward,” the health minister said.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Isabella Moore for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists at Bondi Beach in Australia in February.

item.title: An inquiry into the U.K. government’s pandemic response will include a focus on bereaved families.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Walking through Covent Garden in London in November 2020, on the night before new lockdown restrictions were introduced in England.

item.title: ‘Economic War’
item.description: Which companies have pulled out of Russia — and which have not?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: In line for an A.T.M. of Alfa Bank in Moscow.

item.title: Lockdowns Spread in China as Covid Cases Surge in Shanghai and Other Areas
item.description: Officials say that most of the recent cases detected in widespread testing are asymptomatic but still contagious.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Lining up for coronavirus tests in a residential neighborhood in Shanghai on Thursday.

item.title: Indian State That Covid Hit Hard Is Now Recording Sharply Lower Deaths
item.description: The western state of Maharashtra on Wednesday reported no daily fatalities from the virus for the third time this month.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Commuters at a train station in Mumbai last week.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Russian forces surround Ukrainian cities.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers standing guard in Maidan Square in Kyiv.

item.title: Biden Will Call for Suspending Normal Trade Relations With Russia
item.description: The move, expected to be joined by the G7 and the European Union, would result in higher tariffs on Russian products being sent to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Katie Rogers
item.media:description: Shipping containers at a commercial port in Vladivostok, Russia, in October.

item.title: Climate Change’s Threat to the Glorious Redwood, Both Here and Afar
item.description: In 1936, foresters planted California redwoods in Victoria. How long will they grow in peace?
item.dc:creator: Meghan Dansie
item.media:credit: Jade Byrnes for The New York Times
item.media:description: California redwoods in Victoria, Australia.

item.title: Requests for compassionate release filed by federal prisoners swelled during the pandemic, a study finds.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A federal correction institution in Tucson, Ariz. Data shows that Covid has killed prisoners at higher rates than the general population.

item.title: U.S. Fights Bioweapons Conspiracy Theory Pushed by Russia and China
item.description: The Biden administration says the two countries’ promotion of anti-U.S. conspiracy theories might be cover for lethal Russian military operations.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, left, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in 2019. The two leaders have grown closer, largely because of a shared desire to undermine American global dominance.

item.title: Russia Batters and Encircles Ukrainian Cities, as Diplomacy Falters
item.description: The first meeting during the war of the two countries’ foreign ministers yielded no cease-fire. The Russian side signaled that its invasion would not stop until Ukraine surrendered.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yelena Lavinska, 22, in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, on Thursday, mourning her fiancé, a Ukrainian soldier who was killed in combat.

item.title: Facing Economic Calamity, Putin Talks of Nationalizing Western Businesses
item.description: With the ruble collapsing, the economy contracting and people abandoning the country, Russia’s leader talks of a Western plot to destroy the country.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A supermarket in Moscow last month. With a plummeting ruble, prices have doubled recently, as Western sanctions bite.

item.title: Citizen Seismologists Track Haiti’s Earthquakes
item.description: When conventional seismometers in Haiti failed before the 2010 quake, cheaper, less sophisticated devices helped seismic researchers fill in the blanks.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: Valerie Baeriswyl for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cleanup near Camp-Perrin in Haiti in the aftermath of the earthquake that struck last August.

item.title: Parents of young children face tough questions after new vaccine findings.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Parents and students registering for Pfizer vaccine shots in New York City last year.

item.title: Thirteen Governors Want the Public Health Emergency Extended Beyond April
item.description: In a letter to the U.S. health secretary, the governors, all Democrats, said they needed more time to prepare for when the emergency expires, taking with it federal resources that state programs depend on.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat and Ada Petriczko
item.media:credit: Cathy Cheney/Portland Business Journal via AP
item.media:description: Oregon Gov. Kate Brown and 12 other governors wrote a letter to Health Secretary Xavier Becerra urging him to extend the country’s public health emergency declaration.

item.title: ISIS Names a New Leader, but Says Little About Him
item.description: The terrorist group announced its new leader as Abu al-Hasan al-Hashimi al-Qurashi, but gave no information about his background or true identity.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A faded flag of the Islamic State in Raqqa, Syria, in 2018.

item.title: Poland’s Tourism Industry Is Helping Ukrainian Refugees
item.description: As Ukrainians flood into Poland, the travel industry has become part of an effort to supply transportation, accommodations and more to people fleeing the Russian invasion.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu and Magdalena Chodownik

item.title: ‘Inadequate’ Security Led to Deaths of 3 Americans in Kenya Attack, Report Finds
item.description: The inquiry also found shortcomings in the sharing of intelligence before the deadly assault by the Shabab in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Caroline Brehman/CQ Roll Call, via Associated Press
item.media:description: “We were not as prepared at Manda Bay as we needed to be,” Gen. Stephen J. Townsend, the commander of Africa Command, said at a presentation of the report’s findings at the Pentagon on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia Makes Slow Advances
item.description: Talks in Turkey ended without agreement.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yelena Lavinska, 22, joined by relatives, friends, and comrades, mourned the death of her fiance, Ukrainian soldier, Mikhailo Pristupa, who was shot and killed in combat in Irpin on March 5, during his wake and funeral at the Baikove Cemetery in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Says North Korea Is Testing a New Intercontinental Missile
item.description: The missile, first displayed in 2020, was tested twice in recent days. While it is unclear whether it can reach the U.S., it poses a new military challenge to President Biden in the midst of the Ukraine war.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: KCNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: It is not clear whether the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, timed the tests to come at a time of maximum distraction in Washington and fear of a broader war in Europe.

item.title: IMF Warns Ukraine-Russia War Will Likely Slow Global Growth
item.description: The economic fallout from Russia’s invasion will depend on the outcome of the war and the duration of the sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers standing guard in Maidan Square in Kyiv on Wednesday.

item.title: Stellantis Stops Car Shipments to and From Russia
item.description: The automaker has been making delivery vans in Russia, but its chief has said production is likely to halt because of a lack of parts.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:description: The Stellantis plant in Kaluga, Russia, which is owned in partnership with Mitsubishi, in 2019.

item.title: An Exiled Theater With a Warning for Europe
item.description: The Belarus Free Theater’s members fled repression at home. The company’s latest show imagines a nightmare future of authoritarian Russian rule.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Jeremie Souteyrat for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rehearsal for “Dogs of Europe,” which opens at the Barbican theater in London on Thursday.

item.title: As War Rages, a Struggle to Balance Energy Crunch and Climate Crisis
item.description: Rising oil prices and increased demand for expanded production come at a time when scientists say nations must sharply cut the use of fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer, Lisa Friedman and David Gelles
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Omsk, Russia. Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has caused the price of crude oil to skyrocket, approaching $130 per barrel this week.

item.title: Iraqi Minister Says High Oil Prices Could Speed the Shift to E.V.s
item.description: Whatever the short-term benefits for producers, the market upheaval could accelerate the transition away from oil, he says.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: Ihsan Abdul Jabbar, Iraq’s oil minister, in Baghdad in January. He said Middle Eastern oil producers feared high prices could reduce reliance on oil.

item.title: Harris, in Poland, Seeks to Present United Front Against Russia
item.description: Vice President Kamala Harris visited Warsaw a day after U.S. officials said they were blindsided by Poland’s offer to provide jet fighters to Ukraine. Washington rejected it, fearing it could escalate the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris and President Andrzej Duda of Poland during a news conference on Thursday in Warsaw.

item.title: Major Music Companies Pause Business in Russia
item.description: The three major record conglomerates and the touring giant Live Nation are suspending operations over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, while individual artists have canceled tour dates.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Green Day canceled a planned Moscow show in May “in light of current events.”

item.title: Russian Forces Have Encircled Northern Ukraine City of Chernihiv, The Mayor Says
item.description: Ukrainian forces are battling to keep some roads open, as Russia tightens its cordon around the battered city. “We are surrounded,” the mayor said.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: After days of shelling, the city of Chernihiv has become mostly surrounded by Russian forces.

item.title: 4 Falsehoods Russians Are Told About the War
item.description: Russia’s disinformation machine is working in overdrive inside its own borders.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:description: An apartment building in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday, that was destroyed after shelling.

item.title: Russia’s civilian attacks
item.description: We tell you the story of a Ukrainian family that has become an international symbol of civilian death.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Here are the latest developments in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Anton Troianovski and Shashank Bengali

item.title: BTS Performs Live in Seoul for First Time in Over 2 Years
item.description: The K-pop group returned to the stage in South Korea on Thursday, although fans were not allowed to cheer, scream or sing along because of Covid restrictions.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Fans arriving for the BTS concert at Seoul Olympic Stadium on Thursday.
